11:11 am

PM

A par from Paul Donovan

PM

The Fed was divided in tone yesterday – both Williams and Yellen stressed "gradual tightening" but the former with more urgency than the latter. This division of central bank emphasis is a global consequence of multifaceted policy options. It comes down to the conditions Yellen identified. We see upside risks to core US inflation, a dollar that is stable to weaker, and a Euro area economy that outperforms consensus – all of which suggest that the Fed should be raising rates this year.

11:12 am
BE

And some SocGen ......

BE

A dominant theme over the past six weeks has been the
decoupling between risk assets and bonds (Graph 1, LHS).
Central banks have played a key role, with the dovish tone
supporting both risk taking and bonds. Yet again Yellen
was true to her dovish instincts on Tuesday, as she
focused on global headwinds. “This caution is especially
warranted because, with the federal funds rate so low, the
FOMC’s ability to use conventional monetary policy to
respond to economic disturbances is asymmetric.”

BE

11:13 am
BE

A further rally in risk would likely make the Fed less dovish.
But we’d rather see the risk rally running out of steam on
its own, and that could support bonds, with signs of
fatigue of late in both the oil rally and the dollar (Graph 1,
RHS) with these moves at the heart of the risk complex.
The global economic news is mixed at best; even in the
US, soft personal spending has led to some downgrades
to Q1 GDP, as reflected by NowCast indices (e.g. the
Atlanta Fed here now tracks at +0.6% only). Cash flows
are set to support bonds in Europe over April, as we
emphasised yesterday (Ten ideas to celebrate spring). The
start of the new fiscal year in Japan may support western
bonds too; at 193bp the 10-year UST-JGB spread is in the
upper end of the range over the past year.
So bonds are not about to turn the corner. The 10-year
Bund is heading towards the end-February low at just
10bp, and then last year’s record low (near 8bp). Our
forecasts have 10y Bund at negative levels in Q2.

Premier Foods wishes to clarify that Mr Darby was not aware, nor could he have been, of any discussions between McCormick & Company, Inc. and Warburg Pincus. He was simply seeking to make clear, in response to a question from the journalist, that it would have been open to any party, including McCormick & Company, Inc., at any time to approach Warburg Pincus with a view to purchasing all or part of their shareholding.

BE

Count the she subordinate clauses involved here.

BE

11:17 am

BE

11:17 am
BE

Who, I assume, have now thrown a blanket over Mr Darby and locked him in a shed.

BE

I mean, there was also this (again from the Telegraph's Ashley Armstrong, who's been on this story like glue.)

BE

PREMIER Foods told Japan's Nissin it had received a takeover approach from an American suitor before any of its existing shareholders and before the noodle maker bought a 17.3pc stake in the British food manufacturer, it has emerged.

The Bisto and Mr Kipling owner sparked anger in the City last week after revealing it had rejected a 60p-ashare takeover offer from McCormick in favour of a commercial agreement with Nissin. The offer, which was rejected out of hand by Premier's board, valued the business at £495m.

Within 24 hours, Nissin had bought a 17.3pc stake in Premier from private equity house Warburg Pincus. Investors feared that Nissin's stake building, which hands it a right to a board seat, would dissuade McCormick or any other bidder from making an offer for the full company. But the revelation that Premier told Nissin about the American approach - before disclosing it to existing investors - will further incense disgruntled shareholders.

11:19 am

11:25 am
BE

Shore Cap is thinking along similar lines .......

BE

US based McCormick has today announced it is today making a revised proposal to the Board of Premier Foods of 65p cash per share, on the basis of prompt and full engagement from the company; 65p represents an 8.3% premium to the previously announced proposal of 60p and a 25% premium to the 52p initial approach.

The deal values Premier’s equity at £537m, and would represent a March 2017 PER of 7.7x, and an EVP/EBITDA of 9.7x (assuming P is £390m, the discounted value of future cash flows into the pension).

We see 65p as a good compromise price, allowing Premier’s management to highlight the extra value it has extracted from McCormick, whilst also offering shareholder’s the opportunity of a cash exit today at a reasonably full EBITDA valuation rather than waiting for the chance of a higher price through operational improvement highlighted by the company in its statement to the market last week, which is not without risk.

Accordingly, we suggest stakeholder’s should ACCEPT the 65p offer, noting the involvement of Nissin as a minority shareholder (17%), though with the current share price now implying less than 10% upside we move recommendation to HOLD (from BUY).

11:33 am
PM

Additional analysis of sections of core obtained from the Icewine#1 exploration well has confirmed outstanding permeability in two previously unmeasured core samples. These core samples had readings too high to be measured using the traditional method for estimating permeability in tight rocks and have therefore been measured using pulse decay permeability analysis. The results of this analysis have indicated that permeability in these core sections is approximately 20 times greater than the Company's pre-drill forecasts for permeability in the HRZ at Project Icewine.

GlaxoSmithKline PLC (GSK:LSE): Last: 1,412, up 20 (+1.44%), High: 1,420, Low: 1,408, Volume: 3.19m
BE

Andrew Baum of Citi has upgraded.

BE

He has a following.

11:37 am
BE

Summary and Investment Conclusion.
We are upgrading GSK to Buy from Neutral. Our 12m price target remains £15.50. We have not had a Buy rating on GSK for over 3 years. Our SOTP-based DCF Intrinsic Value is £17.60. The modest pipeline is credible and undervalued in our view, especially within oncology (near term epigenetics, longer term IO including cell therapy). R&D and business development leadership is improving from a low historic base. The planned appointment of a new CEO in 2017 increases the possibility of a value enhancing divestment/spin of the consumer business and augmented cost reduction. We prefer Buy rated Roche, GSK, and AZN in EU; BMY and LLY in US.

BE

So ....... Breakup?

BE

We have historically struggled to recommend GSK given our concerns over historic R&D and BD judgments, Corporate Integrity Agreement (CIA) impact, dividend over-distribution and generic pressures. Many of these concerns are resolving or set to resolve. The new Chairman continues to preside over material senior management and board changes, as well as rebasing mid-term Advair expectations. Separately, the CIA is set to expire in July 2017 facilitating a more aggressive US marketing approach under the incoming CEO.

11:38 am
BE

So ........ Breakup?

BE

We have highlighted the potentially transformative potential of epigenetics in our recent report Epigenetic Drugs. The Next Big Big Thing?. GSK will present phase I data from their I-BET GSK’762 at AACR across multiple solid tumors. I-BET has the potential to reverse resistance to other chemotherapies, potentiate immunotherapies and address non cancer indications. We anticipate un-risk-adjusted peak sales of £1.5bn (£810m risk adjusted).

BE

Yeah, but breakup?

11:38 am
BE

GSK & Miltenyi are set to build a point of care automated cell therapy network in local hospitals enabling wider use of TCR, CART cells, engineered NK cell therapy. GSK will present initial OX40, anti-BCMA ADC data at AACR in April. The ROI for GSK’s grand cell therapy vision is unclear given sparse data, competing off the shelf approaches, regulatory and logistical hurdles.

PM

So...?

BE

Our positive investment thesis is not contingent on divestment or spin of GSK’s consumer business.

11:38 am
BE

Nuts.

BE

The timing of the departure of Sir Andrew and the near term pressure on Novartis’s Core EPS likely preclude any decision until 2018. We are doubtful that Novartis will exercise its 2018 put option given mid-term pressures on Novartis’s earnings, in light of the recent disclosure of State Attorney General’s expanded investigation under the FCA (click here). We estimate the Consumer JV Business to have an intrinsic value of £4.76 per share on a stand-alone basis. A potential acquisition of the Consumer business at 5 times forward sales (2018e) in 2018 would raise an estimated £38bn or £7.9 per share.

BE

We'll get that "Reckitt to buy GSK Consumer" story eventually, just not today.

11:47 am
BE

Speaking of Anglo, here's Morgan Stanley.

BE

Too many hurdles to the Bull case

BE

So that's a bull case that's disentangling a leg but facing too many hurdles.

11:48 am
BE

The extended metaphor still kinda works.

BE

AAL's transformation plan is positive, but a high level of conviction
in the bull case is needed to offset the 90%+ downside to our bear
case. The hurdles look challenging – re-rating to transaction
multiples in diamonds, a value for the halted Quellaveco project and
execution on disposals. UW

BE

Our most bullish transformation scenario could offset the bear case
downside. AAL is divesting assets to focus solely on Copper, Platinum and
Diamonds. The implied valuation of these core assets at today's share price is
7.1x EV/EBITDA. That is not particularly attractive versus the weighted average
of its peers at 7.6x. However, in our most bullish scenario we estimate a value
post transformation of GBp1070 – 117% upside. That could be enough to
offset the 90%+ downside risk we see in the bear case.
But a rerating to 2011/2012 transaction multiples is a stretch ... In our
GBp1070 bull case we value De Beers at US$14 billion EV or 13.5x EV/EBITDA
2016e, based on AAL's purchase of the additional 40% of the equity in 2012.
This is almost three times the multiple of nearest peer Alrosa. We also value
AAL's Quellaveco copper project at US$3.6 billion, similarly based on a 2011
M&A transaction. This re-rating could prove hard to achieve as a listed entity
rather than as part of an M&A transaction. Our bull case drops to GBp590
(20% upside) when we exclude the highly uncertain copper project and value
diamonds at 7x 2016/17 EV/EBITDA, still a 50% premium to Alrosa. That is not
enough to compensate for the bear case risk, in our view.
…and there is execution risk around the asset disposals. In the bull case
net debt declines by US$7 billion to US$6 billion. Divestments contribute just
over US$6 billion to this, we estimate. The risks to that target are the limited
pool of potential buyers and value leakage from transaction costs and taxation.
After delevering, the net debt to EBITDA for the core assets would still be 2.1x
in 2017e or 2.8x adjusting for minorities.
Declining iron ore prices and financial leverage are the key share price
drivers near term. Stay UW. Iron ore is 13% of AAL's 2016e sales, and every
US$10/t in iron ore swings FCF by US$0.3 billion adjusted for minorities. AAL
is the highest cost seaborne iron ore producer, with cash costs exceeding those
of BHP, Rio Tinto and Vale by US$10/t. We expect iron ore prices to drop by
US$26/t to US$30/t into 4Q16, while AAL's net debt to EBITDA remains
elevated at 2.1x 2016e or 3x adjusted for minorities, on spot.

BE

BE

Downgrading William Hill post last week's profit warning.

11:57 am
BE

It's odd how quickly these things change. A few weeks ago William Hill was the online leader so worth a few quid even though it was slowing.

BE

One profit warning later, the online leadership is framed as a curse rather than a benefit.

BE

11:58 am
BE

Post profit warning, we've seen a huge shift in perception -- at least among the sellside -- that it's ex growth and too expensive in spite of being basically incapable of disappointing at a cashflow level.

BE

Whatever. Here's MOST on WMH.

BE

Or would be, if Acrobat hadn't crashed.

11:59 am
BE

One moment.

BE

1. What caused the profits warning ? The Board was "confident in the
outlook for the year ahead" at the FY15 results 26 days earlier, but now
expects EBIT c.£40m lower. The scale of the deterioration in a short period
reflects a £10-15m sports results hit and a £20-25m hit from extrapolating last
week's run-rate of account closures, made easier under new regulations.
2. Have profit expectations been sufficiently rebased? We see this as the
critical issue. With a review ongoing and a potential need for increased
marketing and product spend, risks remain to the downside.
3. Is WHO still a leading Online operator? Its large scale (with £662m
revenue in 2015 it was the number 4 online operator globally) and strong
track record suggest this could be a blip in an otherwise strong growth trend.
But poor sports margins, market share losses, management change and a
sluggish growth profile mean we think it warrants a lower multiple than peers
until it returns to double-digit growth.
4. Do the cashflow and balance sheet provide enough support? William
Hill is returning up to 10% of its market cap this year. However, we think
increasing leverage ahead of a triennial review of machines carries some risk
given the political pressure against machines, outlined here.
Cut to Underweight. With the Online division faltering at a time of
heightened regulatory risk in Retail, we think the risk-reward profile has
deteriorated sharply, and we cut our Bear Case to 165p (12x Bear Case EPS of
14p), suggesting 50% downside risk. Our 470p bull case suggests 42% upside
potential if Online returns to double-digit growth. We now expect an EBIT
CAGR of -1% from 2015-2018e, from 6%, and with the lower growth profile
and faltering Online division, our PT reduction of c.30% is above our mid-term
EPS cuts of c.18%.
